title: 113_s274
content: The Act may be cited as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act". It includes definitions for key terms. The Act, also known as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act", defines key terms such as elementary school, local educational agency, secondary school, and State educational agency according to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It also defines "programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education" as initiatives that enhance students' ability to choose and consume healthy foods. The curr_chunk discusses the importance of providing comprehensive education on healthy eating for students, using scientifically sound and developmentally appropriate nutritional materials. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of professional development programs for teachers, school staff, and food service workers to promote healthy eating and nutrition in schools, in line with the Dietary Guidelines for Americans. Programs are established to promote healthy eating and nutrition education. Local educational agencies receiving assistance under part A of Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in all schools they serve. This may involve integrating such programs into various activities. The programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools include integrating activities throughout the school day and locations, using educational materials emphasizing knowledge of healthy foods and a balanced diet. The school programs focus on promoting healthy eating and nutrition education by integrating activities, emphasizing knowledge of healthy foods, and monitoring efforts to improve students' understanding of nutrition. Local educational agencies must consult multiple viewpoints when developing programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education, including families, students, school officials, and community members. They should also collaborate with organizations with nutrition education expertise, such as higher education institutions, hospitals, and extension offices. Local educational agencies should collaborate with various organizations, including government authorities like Team Nutrition and community groups, to develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. Local educational agencies should collaborate with organizations for technical assistance in designing programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education in schools. This includes working with wellness councils and integrating programs for healthy eating. Local educational agencies are required to integrate programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education with school wellness policies. They must also provide professional development on nutrition education to staff members. State educational agencies receiving assistance under Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act must submit to these requirements. The Education Act of 1965 requires State educational agencies to report on programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education, including monitoring data from local educational agencies. An inter-agency task force will be established by the Secretaries of Education, Agriculture, and Health and Human Services to review and recommend effective nutrition education programs for schools. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these initiatives. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2014 through 2019 to support nutrition education programs in schools.
